source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: three zirconium, tin, niobium, iron, and chromium (Zr-Sn-Nb-Fe-Cr) alloy compositions (VAZ series) with superior corrosion resistance and equivalent mechanical properties to those of conventional Zircaloy-4 were determined

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: equivalent mechanical properties to those of conventional Zircaloy-4

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: The alloys of these compositions were vacuum arc melted in $S - k \cdot g$ ingots and were fabricated into sheets with various annealing parameters.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: They were subjected to long-term corrosion tests in water at ${ \bf 6 3 3 ~ K }$ and tension tests at room and elevated $( 6 5 8 \mathrm { \bf K } )$ temperatures.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: They were subjected to long-term corrosion tests in water at ${ \bf 6 3 3 ~ K }$ and tension tests at room and elevated $( 6 5 8 \mathrm { \bf K } )$ temperatures.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk1
evidence_span: Results showed that the corrosion weight gains and the hydrogen uptakes of VAZ alloys were about $50 \%$ and 20 to $60 \%$ of that of Zircaloy-4, respectively

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk1

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: oxidation of Zircaloy-4 in steam at high temperatures was generated at atmospheric pressure

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: oxidation may be enhanced

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: Lengths of Zircaloy-4 were heated to temperatures between 750 and 1000°C while being exposed to flowing steam at pressures up to 18.6 MPa for durations up to 2500 s

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: Lengths of Zircaloy-4 were heated to temperatures between 750 and 1000°C while being exposed to flowing steam at pressures up to 18.6 MPa for durations up to 2500 s

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: oxide thicknesses were measured by metallography

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: oxidation was enhanced by pressure over this temperature range

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: The deleterious effect increased with temperature up to 900°C where the oxide thicknesses were up to five times greater than expected from atmospheric pressure data

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: Where breakaway oxidation occurred, the local oxide thicknesses were up to a factor of seven greater than predicted

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: At 1000°C, the effect was less pronounced than at 900°C, with maximum enhancement factors of around two

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: At 800°C, the enhancement saturated around 15.2 MPa, when further increases in pressure to above normal pressurized water reactor (PWR) operating pressure had no further noticeable effect

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: Scatter in the data at 900°C prevented identification of any firm trends but the indications were that here the effect did not saturate in the pressure range considered

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: predictive models based on atmospheric pressure data are likely to substantially underestimate the extent of oxidation when Zircaloy-4 is heated in elevated pressure steam

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: zirconium alloys, oxidation, high temperature, high pressure, steam, zirconium, nuclear materials, nuclear applications, radiation effects

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: oxidation performance of Zircaloy-4 in steam atmospheres at high temperatures, such that the kinetics are well quantified to 1600°C and beyond

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_026_chunk4
evidence_span: most of this oxidation data was generated at atmospheric pressure
